Dialogue.Page: You’re actually blasting off in that thing, huh?

DialogueOption.Text: They really don’t explode as often anymore.
I’m told my odds of survival are statistically quite high.
Yep. Might try to fly my ship into that big locked Nomai door and break it down, see what's inside.

Dialogue.Page: Hmph. You go ahead and try that, hatchling, go right on ahead.
I'm telling you now, same thing as I tell that Tektite - ain't nothin' to see in there but evil spirits and curses.
For all we know, we'll find the Nomai's crypts in there.
Whatever's in there, the Nomai wanted it locked up behind a big, impenetrable door for good reason. No good poking four eyes where they don't belong.
Oh - and good luck explaining breaking your new ship to Slate after you try that, too. They'll wring your neck while I give you the smug look.
All I know is between the space program and Mica’s model rockets, things seem to burn to the ground around here more than they used to.
Yeah, the space program’s certainly come a long way. I should probably thank you for causing fewer flash fires than your predecessors.
By the way, good luck with those retro rockets.
Hey, what can I do for you?

DialogueOption.Text: Marl is plotting to cut down that big tree. Again.
Are you going to watch the launch?
Do you really worry that the space program will burn the village down?
Yep. Might try to fly my ship into that big locked Nomai door and break it down, see what's inside.

Dialogue.Page: <Color=#808080ff>Sigh...</Color> I suppose it’s my duty as mayor to stop them. Again.
When Marl fell out of that tree and broke their arm, I suspect they might have also hit their head on the way down.
Only constantly. You learn to live with it.
You also learn to sleep with a bucket of water next to your bed, just in case.
I’ll be watching from a safe distance, obviously, and mostly to make sure nothing catches fire. But watching nonetheless.
You’re back already? Is everything OK?
